channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: White House in No Rush on Syria Action
item.description: The White House said it would seek further information about the use of chemical weapons in Syria before deciding whether President Obama’s “red line” had been crossed.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Musharraf Under Arrest on Charges in Bhutto Assassination
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s former military leader, is accused of threatening Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister, before she returned to Pakistan from exile in 2007.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Violent Protests Follow Building Collapse in Bangladesh
item.description: The protests came as rescue teams spent a third day searching for survivors in the rubble of a building that collapsed in a suburb of the capital, killing more than 300.
item.category: Children s Place Retail Stores Inc|PLCE|NASDAQ
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police fired tear gas after relatives of the missing and dead burst into angry protests at the site of a building collapse on Friday in Savar, Bangladesh.

item.title: Shadows of an Old Military Base
item.description: The Subic Bay Freeport in the Philippines was once filled with free-spending U.S. sailors. Now it has both tourist attractions and abandoned American-style homes and buildings.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Subic Bay has become a popular tourist destination for Filipinos seeking to enjoy the beaches and the American legacy of the former military base.

item.title: At War Blog: Should Gun Restrictions Be Placed on Veterans With PTSD?
item.description: A Marine Corps veteran turned journalist explores the contentious issue of whether veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder should be allowed to possess firearms.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS JAMES BRENNAN

item.title: Parents Say Boston Bombing Suspects Are Innocent
item.description: At an emotional news conference, Anzor and Zubeidat Tsarnaev made accusations of a conspiracy theory and refused to accept the possibility that their children committed a bombing.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anzor Tsarnaev, left, and Zubeidat Tsarnaeva said on Thursday that their sons had no connections to radical Islamist groups.

item.title: Southern Europe’s Recession Threatens to Spread North
item.description: Germany and other nations in Northern Europe could be caught in the recession of Southern Europe, which would slow the continent’s recovery and hinder growth worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: An ominous sign in Spain, where the unemployment rate is a staggering 27.2 percent.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Hospital Wing Collapses in India
item.description: The authorities said the collapse at the hospital in Bhopal, India, seriously injured at least four people and left more than a dozen trapped.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 26
item.description: A sports ground in Mumbai, Maharashtra, being watered as temperatures in the city soared.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A sports ground in Mumbai, Maharashtra, being watered, as the temperature in the city crossed 36 degrees Celsius, or 96.8 degrees Fahrenheit, the highest in April so far.

item.title: WORLD: U.S. Suspects Chemical Weapons in Syria
item.description: A look at mounting pressure on the Obama administration after the White House said Thursday that it believes the Syrian government has used chemical weapons.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Swiss Quotas Highlight Europe’s Immigration Debate
item.description: Under pressure from a populist campaign, the Swiss government has moved to curb migrant numbers from the European Union. The debate in Switzerland has echoed a growing anti-immigration mood elsewhere in the Continent.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Switzerland's justice minister, Simonetta Sommaruga, acknowledged that the purpose of quotas is to stem political opposition to immigration.

item.title: German Equality, Enforced in Names
item.description: Some German localities are striving to give notable women their due in public spaces with strict rules on labeling.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: For Indonesian Atheists, a Community of Support Amid Constant Fear
item.description: In predominantly Muslim Indonesia, where trumpeting one's disbelief in God can lead to abuse, ostracism and even prison, atheists find careful ways to build a community of support.
item.dc:creator: By SARA SCHONHARDT

item.title: 38 Killed in Fire at Russian Psychiatric Hospital
item.description: Most of the victims were patients who died in their beds as firefighters made the hourlong journey from the nearest station, safety officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Emergency services workers carried a body bag after a fire at Psychiatric Hospital No. 14 in the town of Ramensky, near Moscow.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 26
item.description: The White House says Syria has used chemical weapons; the U.N. votes for a peacekeeping force in Mali; questions about the Bangladesh factory building collapse; teacher protests in Mexico; and a superb production of “Othello” in London.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: A French soldier in Gao, Mali, this month. France sent troops to Mali in January to push the Islamist militants out of the north.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Beauty Market Resists Recession
item.description: Economic hard times have failed to dent the enthusiasm of Europeans for beauty treatments. But health experts are sounding alarms about potential health risks of some of those treatments.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS

item.title: South Korea to Pull Workers from North
item.description: The decision to remove 175 managers from a jointly operated industrial park came hours after North Korea rejected the South’s proposal for talks.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Cameron Cites Evidence of Chemical Warfare in Syria
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron, speaking on a BBC show, echoed the caution of the Obama administration and ruled out direct British military intervention.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: And the Oliviers Will Go to . . .
item.description: The IHT’s theater critic handicaps the field for this year’s Laurence Olivier Awards, London’s version of the Tonys.
item.dc:creator: By MATT WOLF
item.media:description: Johnny Flynn (Viola) and Mark Rylance (Olivia) in "Twelfth Night" at the Apollo Theatre in London.

item.title: India Ink: Messages From Sunil Tripathi’s Family and Brown University on His Death
item.description: The body of the Brown University student, who was briefly misidentified as a suspect in the Boston bombings, found in the waters off of India Point Park near Providence, R.I.
item.dc:creator: By SHIVANI VORA

item.title: 36 Killed in Fire at Russian Psychiatric Hospital
item.description: Most of the victims were patients at a psychiatric hospital outside Moscow who were confined to the building because of their mental ailments.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: François Jacob, Geneticist Who Pointed to How Traits Are Inherited, Dies at 92
item.description: Dr. Jacob was a French war hero whose combat wounds forced him to change his career paths from surgeon to scientist, a pursuit that led to a Nobel Prize in 1965.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: François Jacob, left, and Jacques Monod in 1971. They helped discover how genes are regulated.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Lawmakers Pass Contentious Secrecy Bill
item.description: South Africa’s Parliament on Thursday passed a much-criticized secrecy bill that will restrict access to information and impose hefty fines and jail terms on reporters who publish information the government classifies as secret.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Cuba: U.S. Bars Raúl Castro’s Daughter From a Forum
item.description: The State Department denied the daughter of President Raúl Castro of Cuba permission to attend a gay rights conference in Philadelphia, where she was to receive an award next week.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Attack on Party Office Kills 5 People
item.description: A bomb exploded in Karachi outside an election office of one of Pakistan’s main political parties on Thursday evening, killing five people in the latest attack ahead of the nation’s May 11 elections.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
